summary: The U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois today entered a final judgment against a company that filed a siting application for a municipal solid waste transfer station in Will County, Illinois.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Chicago on Dec. 12, 2014, Environmental Recycling and Disposal Services, Inc. (ERDS) filed an application for siting approval in the Will County Service Area.  The complaint alleges that ERDS failed to meet certain criteria in its application, including that the proposed facility would handle an average of 200 tons per day of solid waste, that it could not handle more than 200 tons of waste, and that it did not have the capacity to handle all of the waste.  In addition, the complaint alleged that the application omitted information about the capacity of the transfer station, which was not met by the Pollution Control Board's criteria.  As alleged in the complaint, ERDS also failed to provide evidence that the facility was necessary to meet the requirements of section 39.2(a) of the Environmental Protection Act of 1940.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the court's order, the defendants consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and imposing civil penalties against each of them. The settlements are subject to court approval.
